The dish came with a breathtakingly delicious polenta that was the color and consistancy of fresh cream. Here's how you secure a table at this restaurant. It is very popular, but not impossible to get into. You can always stand at the small bar area and have tastes from the tiny buffet and have a drink. Many Venetians do this. But you really want to dine there. Reservations are vital for regular evening dining hours - 8:00 to 10:00. The restaurant's doors are closed until precisely 6:30. It is not open on Thursday or Sunday. Odd days, but that's their plan. Anyway, at between 6:30 and 6:45 p.m., go there and ask for a table. You should be advised that you can have a space, but must finish eating by 8. Or, of course, you can go in at any time and make reservations for another night or as many nights as you want. Most of the tables are long (rectangular) with dark polished wood, and seat six. But, they are usually set for four. This means you will, if you are dining with only one other person, enjoy a meal with another twosome. This is a great way to meet people and is lots of fun. We ate at here in 2004, arriving very late for that meal. This year, we went in once at 6:45 and ate until 8, and also made a reservation for a second night. On the second night we shared our table with a thirty-something architect from Munich, Germany who was with his 75-year old mother (a great, vibrant lady). He had brought his mom to Venice for the weekend as a birthday present. Nice son. Nice present. It was a terrific meal and the comradery was wonderful. There is a lot to see in Venice, but I do recommend a boat ride to Murano island to see the glassmakers and take in the shops. I also recommend a boat ride to Burano island to see the lacemakers. Burano is also famous for its colorfully painted homes. Both can be done in the same day. The Lido is also a great place to visit. In Venice itself, I was pleasantly surprised by the very eclectic modern art collection at the Peggy Guggenheim Museum on the Grand Canal. Well worth a visit. While taking some back alleys in the Santa Croce neighborhood to get to a vaporetto stop, I happened upon a shop in which a glorious woman, Teresa Della Valentina, makes some of the most incredible hand-painted tiles you've ever seen. The shop is called Arca and is at 1811 Calle Tentor in the Santa Croce section of Venice. Calle tentor is directly off the walk that is near the San Stae vaporetto stop. Stroll south for about three minutes from the stop. Teresa is a true artist and absolutely filled with joy and pride at her work. We bought some more of her amazing tiles. Her range of work and her colors are exceptional. Her photo is included with the batch of photographs I've posted with this review. And, of course, no trip to Venice is complete without a visit to the Rialto Market and a hello to the fabulous Giuliana. The day we were there she was wearing a fantastic leopard print jacket and white sunglasses while selling her terrific produce. I also want to mention a day-long side trip we took from Venice to Bologna. We caught a mid-morning train to this most interesting of cities. Bologna gets very few American tourists and that's unjustified. The train took about two hours and it was worth the ride. The city is fantastic. The archways that cover almost every sidewalk are amazing. There's a great old tower you can go up into (598 steps for 3 euros for a breathtaking view of Bologna and the surrounding hills). Every person in every store we entered (gelateria, restaurant, olive oil and cheese shop) was incredibly friendly and was thrilled Americans had come to their city. Bologna is home to the world's largest university (100,000 students). It has a fascinating old town section. It's a big city without the insane traffic or graffiti that Rome has. The San Maggiore square is huge and the main church - Basilica San Petronius - is truly beautiful. We had a flawless meal at a restaurant where students and professors were hanging out. The place was called Il Ristoro Della Fate and is at 24/f Via Zamboni in the university quarter. I had perfect tortoloni (invented in Bologna, by the way). Trains run constantly, so returning to Venice late at night was not a problem. Venice is unlike most cities you've experienced. My best advice is to get into the swing of things. You will walk. You will boat. You will mrvel at the decay and the beauty. You will get lost. All perfect. I'm happy to call the Hotel Bernardi my home in Venice, and I plan on calling it that on future visits.

Reviews.Title: “A lovely Venetian experience”
Reviews.Author: sandy1548
Reviews.Content: This was our second stay at the Hotel Bernardi. In the 6 years since our last visit the hotel has acquired the annex. It was a pleasure to stay here. I felt like a princess, opening the three doors it took to get to our room, in what felt like a private castle. Our room had a canopy bed and overlooked a private garden. We slept peacefully with the hugh casement windows wide open, looking at the sky and the window boxes of our neighbors. One really knows they are in Venice when staying at this small gem of a hotel. Leonardo and his staff are so cordial and helpful. It is because of this hotel that I long to return to Venice.

Reviews.Title: “fantastic value”
Reviews.Author: Lofty60
Reviews.Content: We loved this hotel, stayed in a huge room in the annexe, king size bed, plus a single bed. It had a good bathroom by European standards, but a very small shower - if you drop the soap, it's too bad! The only complaint I have is that there were no bath mats supplied. Breakfast was average for Italy, fresh bread rolls, with lovely peach jam. We passed on the packaged croissants and fake toast. Juice and coffee/tea also supplied. We found the hotel easy to find by following the map rather than the written instructions. When you get to the square(ss Apostoli) turn down the first little alleyway on the left hand side, the hotel sign sticks out and is easy to see. There are lots of shops around the area, also cafes and restaurants. Everybody speaks English to some degree, but they appreciate if you make an effort to say a few words of Italian.

Reviews.Title: “Book a room with an ensuite!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: My sister, my boyfriend and I booked this room on the recommendation of Lonely Planet guide Western Europe. We paid 85euros/night for a triple with SHARED bathroom. Breakfast was included. Pros: - good location; short walk to Rialto Markets and vaporetto stop if arriving by train from Santa Lucia. - cheap for venice! Cons: - no lift; narrow steep staircase - not so good for mobility impaired people - shared shower was absolutely horrible! we were on the second floor and it seems the first floor shower wasn't working. if you're unlucky enough to be the last person to use the shower in the morning - the floor and wall will be wet with no dry place to put your towel! also, you'd have to turn off the water every now and then as it wouldn't drain properly! i woke up early one day to be one of the first to have a shower and hard as i tried not to make a huge mess for the next person it was impossible as there is a tiny shower curtain (that doesn't reach the floor!) to protect the outside 'shower area' from getting wet. - staff - rude at times; they were friendly initially but when it came to paying there was a problem with the line so the credit card payment wouldn't go through - i paid via maestro in the end. Other things worth mentioning: - we booked a triple tho our room was more of a double with an extra bed - very small. - breakfast - good things were bread with jams and if you're early enough cake and yoghurt; i would avoid the packaged croissants - opposite an internet cafe all in all i would stay here again as its pretty cheap for venice; we didn't spend much time in our rooms so i view it basically as a place to sleep. i would try and book a room with its own shower though in future.

Reviews.Title: “I'd recommend this nice hotel.”
Reviews.Author: windriverfamily
Reviews.Content: We were very happy to be able to stay at the Hotel Bernardi. We arrived very early via the night train from Paris, and Leonardo was kind enough to let us stash our luggage until our room was ready in the early afternoon. We easily found the hotel via the hotel site map and directions from Frommers. Our annex room was BIG, quiet, and had delicious air conditioning. We even had a clothes-line outside our bathroom window! Their breakfasts, served in the main building, gave us a good start to the day. We really appreciated the old-world manners of Leonardo, who returned our emails promptly.

Reviews.Title: “Great Hotel for Low Price”
Reviews.Author: UptownCat
Reviews.Content: We stayed in the Annex and really liked this hotel. Very clean, good service, and well located.

Reviews.Title: “Bernardi is reasonably priced, decent hotel in pricey Venice!”
Reviews.Author: netplayn
Reviews.Content: Spent only one night in Venice at the Bernardi. Booked it based on TripAdvisor reviews. As stated by others, it is a bit difficult to find at first - especially for someone new to Venice who may be a little hesitant to go down some narrow streets. Although I had it mapped out, we had to ask 2 different people for directions, but we finally found it and were pleasantly surprised. As we are used to staying in 2-star hotels, my husband acted a bit shocked when I told him, as we were putting the key into our room door, that we should have a private bath. I guess he thought that was a given! =) Nevertheless, although the room was small, it was by no means cramped. It was clean and in what we thought was a safe area. The vaporetto stop was super close and restaurants/shops are plentiful in the area. An easy walk to the Rialto Bridge and San Marco (there are signs to direct you along the way), we only got "lost" once - at night. It is difficult in Venice to maintain one's sense of direction - even for those of us with good sense! =) Our double room was next to the toilet, but we did not hear anyone ever use it. Our room was quiet and the bed was good. The room had a small television and a coffee/tea maker, which was nice. We did not eat breakfast at the hotel, as we left too early. Compared to the prices of other hotels in Venice, the Bernardi was a great bargain. We paid 85 Euro for a double room. Although we had air conditioning, it did not seem to work well.

Reviews.Title: “clean and great value”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Family of 4, First I must say I had read all reviews and tried to take them with a grain of salt. I understand everyone is different when it comes to expectations of hotel rooms but, if you have traveled anywhere in europe you should not expect private owned hotels to be like the holiday inn or hilton. I made the resevations here over the internet and had several contacts with the owners with no problems. we reserved the room about 6 weeks before and got a price of 130 euros for a quad 2 adult/2 kids and that is a great price. We did not spend much time in the room but, when we did it was comfortable and quiet and had an a/c unit in room. We also had breakfast both mornings they had coffee (not instant), hot chocolate, juice, rolls, fruit, yogurt, and pasteries. Nothing exotic but a good start to the morning. I found Santina and Leonardo very cordial and helpful. I also left my drivers license at the desk because we stayed in the annex and had no problem getting it back when I turned in the keys. This hotel was a great value in a great location (easy to find)( If you find a map and study it alittle before you go) Venice is an old city and as someone else has said Some streets look like small alleys but, they are streets so don't be afraid to go down them when looking for things. We had a fantastic time and look foreward to returning in the future

Reviews.Title: “I'm staying here again in September!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Bernardi Semenzato was a wonderful way to end our two weeks in Italy. A beautiful small hotel tucked back off the main thoroughfare. The directions given by the hotel brought us right to their front door. Originally I had booked the main building as I was traveling with my mother and her bad knee. After having to make last minute changes we ended up in the annex. Beautiful room and bath! The one BIG problem was that we were told the air conditioning was broken in this room...the only room available. I ended up leaving the window open through the night for a breeze and woke up with over 40 mosquito bites! Made for a long trip back to the Pacific NW. But all in all, I would definitely stay here again!

Reviews.Title: “Be careful if you stay here”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Two serious problems: 1. Proprietor insisted on retaining my drivers license for staying in the annex. the license was not returned upon my leaving & paying the bill/returning keys etc. It was also never mailed to me during the rest of my stay in Italy or at home. We found out later that this is illegal. Also unnecessary, since they have Passport & credit card info. 2. Proprietor has a bit of a short fuse - yelling at some of the clients several times for making too much noise. I found his shouting more disconcerting than whatever noise they were supposedly making.

Reviews.Title: “Hotel Bernardi is a Great Value”
Reviews.Author: PatriceH
Reviews.Content: Our room at the Bernardi was in the annex, as requested based on previous comments, and it was large, clean, and furnished nicely. The bath was large and modern. It was very quiet at night. We did not have breakfast at the hotel because of some reviews we had read, but in retrospect wish that we had. Each morning we spent at least as much, if not more, for a pastry and coffee at cafes on the street, and probably would have done just as well or better with the hotel breakfast. The hotel is dificult to find for someone new to Venice. It is located on a small alley/street and we walked past it a couple times before stopping an elderly gentleman, who spoke excellent English, and he directed us to it. The hotel should post a clearer map and give more detailed instructions on its website. It is a great value, and centrally located to many things. We highly recommend it and would definitely stay there again.

Reviews.Title: “***A True Venetian gem***”
Reviews.Author: Chicken_Dinosaur
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Hotel Bernardi during the Carnivale earlier this year (2005) and were suitably impressed, to say the least. We stayed in a spacious, en-suite, annex room (having booked over the phone many months in advance). The room was spacious, clean, bright, and packed a real Venetian punch aesthetically with the ornate mirrors, cupboards, bed, side tables etc. The fact that the hotel is tucked away in a side alley makes it all the more endearing. The manager, Leonardo, was always very friendly and helpful. Location-wise, it's a magical 15 minute walk to St Marks square and everything is reachable by foot. Truly, the best value accomodation in an otherwise overpriced city. Will definitely return. Recommended.

Reviews.Title: “Lovely Hotel”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: I've just come back from staying at the Bernardi Semenzato and was delighted with the two days we spent there; it was an ideal stay for wanting to experiance venice and enjoy a relaxing break. To tell the truth we spent little time in the actual hotel as we had a lot of sight-seeing to cram into the one weekend, however, the room and service of the hotel was more than adequette. It was great that, although we arrived at midnight, the reception was still open and expecting us, and we had a very warm welcome. Although our room's bathroom was in the hallway, it was clean and substancial- and I didn't bump into anyone or have to que at all. Breakfast was fine- it filled our stomachs till we were able to lunch out (even though it was limited and basic) and service was good. Location was perfect- a 4star anywhere else couldn't have been better as where we were situated was in a quiet back alley just off of a nice piazza and one of the main roads in Venice- Strada Nuovo. Everything then was just a little walk away- but in venice no distance seems long as there is just so much to see and admire. And the price for all of this- amazingly low in comparisson to other hotels- what a great deal! Of course if you want a luxury stay in venice then these standards may be a little low- but as I feel to truly experience a place,- a culture then you should do it the local way and if that's modestly-then great! Totally engoyed our stay and will be coming back in the very near future, thankyou to the staff and a little message- 'keep up the great paintings and art work leonardo- I'l be looking out for your name!'

Reviews.Title: “Very good value for Venice”
Reviews.Author: kasperdoggie
Reviews.Content: Enjoyed our stay at Bernardi Semenzato. Our room was spacious, well lit, decent bathroom, great shower pressure and location was very convenient to most sightseeing, especially as there's a vaporetto stop nearby. No problems with the staff whatsoever, did not have breakfast so can not comment. There were a few good cafes and osterias nearby. We would happily come back to this hotel - price to value ratio is pretty high for Venice.

Reviews.Title: “Venetian Gem”
Reviews.Author: Tenoka2000
Reviews.Content: Stayed one night here Nov 8th....very pleasent hotel, nice breakfast. When we made our reservation we inquired about getting an "annex" room as we read that the annex was newer and a little nicer but they were unable to accomodate however the room we had was very nice. Having stayed in several hotels throughout Italy the room was above average. Three of us were sharing the room and did not feel cramped, in fact there was plenty of room for us. We had a private bathroom which was nice however (as is typical) the shower was about 2x3 feet so don't drop the soap! Being curious my wife looked at the shared bath facilities which were down the hall. Interestingly the toilets were down stairs and if you wanted to take a shower you had to go upstairs where the showers were located. The bathrooms were very clean. The hotel is in a great location, you take water taxi #1 and you can walk to the hotel in less than 10 minutes (probably about 5 minutes if you know where you're going once you arrive). Front desk help was polite and helpful. The noise level at this hotel is much better than what we experienced in Rome which was somewhat noisy. You are a 15 minute walk from St Mark's Square and there are great restaurants all over the place. I would stay here again, the price is right, the place is charming and you can't beat the location.

Reviews.Title: “Great family value”
Reviews.Author: Jerseybabs
Reviews.Content: We just returned from Venice with our 3 children, 9,7, and 4. We stayed at the hotel in 2 connecting rooms for a very good price by Venetian standards (120 euros per night.) The staff was very friendly, helped us to get a babysitter, helped us up the stairs with our luggage, took us to the water taxi, etc.. It's in a great part of Venice that's slightly more residential than San Marco. Still, its only a 15 minute walk to St. Mark's, and fairly close to the Rialto Bridge. The rooms were comfortable and clean, the shower is tucked into a tiny corner and could use an update. The breakfast is a roll and coffee, so go try a cornetti and a cappuccino at one of the many places nearby. I didn't see the annex, but judging by the prior reviews it may be a bit more spacious, and have better views. Overall, a very quaint place for the price.

Reviews.Title: “OK Hotel - Good Location”
Reviews.Author: RTWtraveler
Reviews.Content: Hotel Bernardi is OK - especially for Venetian standards. It's not too expensive and you certainly pay for what you get. The room we stayed in was very, very small but clean and the breakfast is basically white bread with jam. The location is really good though. I wouldn't recommend this place (but then again, I wouldn't recommend going to Venice either) but it certainly wasn't the worst place we stayed on our trip.

Reviews.Title: “Disappointing hotel, surly staff , terrible breakfast”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: We were disappointed that this hotel would be recommended as a great little hotel in Venice as it certainly was NOT. Surly unfriendly staff , paper thin walls , lumpy beds and a dreadful breakfast. A dried out roll and instant coffee served by a person with attitude.. On the plus side it is in a good location . We would definitely NOT stay here again.

Reviews.Title: “DUMP!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: This place is a DUMP! It is located in a back alley which STINKS beyond belief. We would have to hold our noses shut as we passed through. You get to the hotel and the reception area is horrendous. It is cluttered, the receptionist wasn't even there. We had to wait 30 minutes because there was no one even attending the front desk. We then were given the keys to our rooms - AND THEN told there is no elevator. We had to haul our lugguge upstairs - since we were on the top floor. The room STANK like cigarette smoke. It still gives me a headache thinking about it. The carpet was disgusting, the sheets and pillows had stains on them. The bathroom was very very small. I didn't even realize it but we were about 3 ft away from the house next door and saw a man staring at me, as I was about teo change. I quickly had to shut the shutters - beware. The day we checked out - we asked them to hold the luggage which meant - leaving it in the back hall by the doorway. totally unattended, no locks, nothing. Since we had bough the Venice Rolling Pass (for people between 18-29 I think it is) - it clearly stated that Hotel Bernardi gives 10% off. They did not honor it. I would NEVER stay in the hotel again and would not recommend it to anyone. I highly recommend you spend a little bit more and get a cleaner, friendlier, and safer place. With a city as amazing as Venice - DO NOT RUIN your experience by staying at a below average - un-humane place like Hotel Bernardi. You will regret it.

Reviews.Title: “Great value - heart of Venice”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Highly recommend - the rooms are small, and the bathrooms even smaller - but for the price you've got a great deal and can splurge on a magnificent dinner or a Murano glass momento with the money you save! Around San Marco, 3 sodas and a coffee cost $30, so a room for $100 a night is a steal. Good, central location and while not in the upscale San Marco area, you can walk there over cobbled streets and tiny canal bridges in less than 20 minutes, or take the Vaporetto (water bus - essential for your stay: get a pass) from a stop less than 3 minutes walk away. Bellisimo!
